title: Drug Encyclopedia - a Linked Data Application for Physicians

author: Jakub Kozák, Department of Software Engineering, Charles University Prague

segmentation: My name is Sarah Cusack and I'm from Charles University in Prague, Ann here to present our project called Drug Encyclopedia.
Which has been running for some time now.
And the main message of my talk is about telling you that it's really possible to build a real world application build on RDF and Sparkle and attract users to it.
So that they use it on a regular basis.
So what am I going to talk about?
A drug encyclopedia?
It's a web application that provides clinically relevant information about drugs and medicinal products to physicians.
I make a distinction between drug Anna medicinal product.
When I say drag, I mean a chemical substance contained in a medicinal product.
Which is like a box of pills or something like that.
Uh.
It's not also a web application.
It contains a integrated data source of the data and you can use it in other ways like.
Using it in some health information system or in an E shop or whatever.
It's built on top of a triple store, so we're directly accessing a triple store each time you click on something in the application.
And the application has been running for almost two years now.
So why did we start it?
Even doing this we have been working with information extraction in medical domain an we started to need some kind of vocabularies or dictionaries about drugs and we realized there is really.
Huge amount of information available on web about drugs and medicine products and so on.
So we went.
Out and ask the physicians if they need something like a integrated data source about.
Drugs and medicinal product.
It turned out that they are using some kind of obsolete old programs or something like that, or just looking it up in a book.
It's kind of slow, non modern.
They don't like it an so we asked him a few questions and they wanted a nice application that's like any any other application they they use on web.
It should contain basic information so they they can skip through the content quickly and not to be bothered by some details that they don't really know.
So it means that they only know the clinically relevant information about drugs.
The patients are telling them about or they want to prescribe.
They wanted also information contained in textual documents called summaries of product characteristics.
Which are?
This is a legal basis for prescription in Czech Republic and I believe many other European Union countries.
And of course, like a Holy Grail for everybody working in drugs is checking drug drug interactions that it's really helpful for them so.
When we had these requirements, we started to choose the information sources, the data sources and we wanted to connect the local information with the international ones.
So it's really important because the local information can somehow be searched in a way, but the international ones it's really hard so.
We selected like.
Macian National Drug file drugbank, etc.
I think it's not that important now.
And started to work in that it's.
It's obvious that these data sources are in different formats.
I've been talking about textual data.
There are also some.
Tables and XML files and so on.
So we.
We decided to use.
RDF for the representation of all of the data sources.
This is some kind of our process that we started with the all kinds of data sources converted it into datasets.
It means that we all everything converted into RDF, including the documents with the inner structure and then linked it together.
It's some kind of standard procedure that I believe many of you know.
So I will not describe it in detail.
It's based on standard stuff.
But The thing is that when you connect the data sources together.
It's.
Then and then you start asking.
Asking questions like query in the form of queries, it's really hard to.
To get the performance on that level that is usable in a web application so.
We design a data Mart on top of of these datasets and link sets which which is a subset of all data contained in the warehouse.
And then also some new informations are calculated.
All these all these processes automatic.
Mostly we use an ETL tool that was developed in our Department for RDF, and the Data Mart is computed with sparkle queries.
So we.
We borrowed this a term from data warehousing and business intelligence, where it means like using specific kind of data for a specific purpose, which is exactly what we're doing.
We want to show only the clinically relevant data to the physicians from all of the drug data that we integrated together.
So we did the data Mart in order to optimize the queries, we design new application ontology.
Which means we assigned new classes to the existing resources.
We also did some kind of entity unification, which means that when an entity is contained in more data sources, we created a new resource and linked all the information about.
About this resource.
To the new one, it can be seen on on this on this slide.
That we, for example, when you need to get a pregnancy category which is contained in FDA labels.
And then you have to traverse really long path to get it.
So we just shorten it that we put.
A new property, gold has begins in category two to the active ingredient.
So the application as I was saying a minute ago is built on top of the Triple Store and each time you click something it triggers the sparkle query.
That's that's the reason we needed to.
Optimize the queries and now we are on times like 10s of milliseconds or hundreds of milliseconds for each for each of page that you see on the.
In the application before I start talking about the features on the next slide, I will show a link that you where you can try the application yourself.
There will be also a QR code if you are able to scan it.
I don't know.
I wasn't anticipating this huge room so.
So be prepared to a user laptops on the next slide if you were if you're interested.
So the main features we build a search and browse it's standard one you can search for product.
You can search for active ingredients.
You can search for diseases for pharmacological actions to get the list of relevant staff you can check for potential interactions.
You can read through the text.
The SBC text Ann in a prototype version.
You can also check for alternative medicine products.
It means basically for cheaper cheaper ones or something like that.
So.
Here is here is the address and also the QR code if you're interested to check it, because maybe it's better if you try it yourself.
Then only seeing the slides that might be not that clear.
Clearly visible so.
The first first thing you see when you go to the application you see a search field where you can put.
When you can type something, it has a autocomplete functionality.
When you type 4, four letters at least, then you will see some suggestions, active ingredients, medicinal products and diseases which you can select.
From the latest or just hit search and then get the complete.
Information.
So.
I hope that everyone if interested.
It's ready, so here is how it looks.
The important thing is that the application is also billed as multilingual, so we have.

For example, information or titles of active ingredients in Czech, English, and Latin, and every time you search something, you search in all languages and the results are shown in the language that is selected in the application of.
For for particular.
User, it's a good thing for physicians because they inject they some Czech Republic.
They sometimes surgeon Latin for the Latin name.
So in this way it's it's easy for them to to search for that.
For each class there is a define a different strategy of search.
It's based on sparkle again, it's configurable, so you can add or remove the classes that you want to search.
And.
Well, that's it.
OK, so when you search for something then you click on it and you go to the detail page.
I'm sorry, probably cannot read it or I don't know.
So it's best when you go to the application.
There is a detail for every every class.
And there are.
Visual templates applied.
It means that we're using.
Special templates for.
For like properties an for literal.
Literals an object is predefined.
You don't have to like.
Change the application every time the data changes.
So if you if you add a new new property and new object, you just extend the sparkle query and there is a default.
Default template that shows the thing on.
On the detail page.
Every every class or object that is shown on the on the detail page is a hyperlink.
So if you click on it you get to another detail page and you can browse the space quite easily and to get information about all the stuff contained in the.
In the space.
And last.
Last functionality or last feature I want to mention besides other others, is the each interact interaction.
Check the information about interactions are integrated from several data sources.
We have also been doing some information extraction about interactions, which is described in a different paper.
And we are providing this information to the user.
So if you are searching for.
For interactions in the application, you go to the home screen and there is a box you can.
You can you can hit and then you type several letters and it will show you the latest and you select it and then the information is checked.
Every pair is checked again.
It's a sparkle query.
This one is taking a little longer.
And.
You see the information from all the data sources that are available in the first one, the ibuprofen at war free and you see like three types of information.
The second one is only one.
So I've said that it's been running for.
Almost two years we are collecting data via Google Analytics and we've been able to attract about 3500 unique users and these are only the users that didn't leave.
Leave the home page immediately so they had to at least go through several pages in the application.
57% of them returned at least once.
And I think the more interesting thing is that 37% of all the users returned more than nine times.
I think that's.
That can be considered at least partially regular user of the application.
We have some friends or colleagues who are using it on regular basis an.
It's.
Popular, we don't do much marketing for it, so maybe later it will attract more more people.
So what have you learned from building this kind of public?
Nation.
Is that I think it was mentioned yesterday on some tutorial keynote or something that the users.
Shouldn't even know that you're using a triplestore because they don't.
They don't care, they don't.
They don't care that you have a triplestore.
As much as they don't care that you're using a relational database, the only thing they're caring about is.
As how fast it performs, how legible it is, or how the information is valid for them.
So the main advantages of using LINQ data or RDF and so on is.
In our opinion on the side of the developers.
It has certain benefits.
Certain risk, you got no schema.
If you can maintain it, and mentally it's a then it's OK.
If you cannot it, it might be a problem.
And that it's easy to add new new data sources, that's.
Pretty obvious.
So again.
Last remark, we have built an application that's using RDF and Sparkle.
We have benefited from that very much.
We build it in like 6 months or something like that.
When two people.
We discovered that the application market is a really good thing for optimization.
And before I left for this conference, we were wondering how much other application?
How many other applications are there to be used by the end users from different domains?
So if you know about any, I would be very, very happy to hear bout more applications built on triple stores for the end too.
So thank you.
So for your last questions to Semantic Web challenge, running at this conference is generally a good place where you can see real applications develop OK, But there are probably many.
Yeah, I'm meaning like being used applications by real users.
OK, cool.
OK, so we have time for questions and do you have any plans of integrating textual data with the link data like there are by medical resources research papers in Pub Med and freely available?
Yes, thank you for the questions.
Yes, we're thinking about integrating also like clinical trials or some new papers from pub.
Med or the libraries from in the Czech Republic and so on.
It's only the people we need to do it.
It's not that it's not that hard because we have mesh integrated and all the libraries or pub Med are using mesh for annotating the papers.
So yes, we would be very happy if we can do it and one more little question.
You mentioned you do path shortening.
Do you do it manually or do you have some heuristics for that?
Yeah, that's a manual procedure.
Thank you.
Hello I have another question so a couple of questions.
Basically number one.
Do you have shown in your slide regarding the data that you have been using?
You explicitly mentioned in the Drug Bank but are you using some other drug sources like Pharma, GCB or other sources?
So this is one spot and other bodies are there practical users like clinical people or physicians directly using this application right now while sitting in their offices or something like that.
So what is the practical use so far?
OK, so the 1st first part of the questions?
Yes, we are using drugbank, we're not using farm KGB or KBR.
How is it?
How is it pronounced now?
Because we're really into the clinically relevant information.

The other resources about drugs are usually about chemicals and the structure of the substances and so on, and it's really not interesting for the people sitting in their offices and like talking to patients, so that's the first part, and the second part, yes, when I set the user shy using in that I know of people that are really using it in the practice where they when they are.
Prescribing drugs.
They have opened this an are searching for that because when the patient comes and he says that he's taking some kind of track, there is a medicine product.
It's a name on the market and they don't know what it is so so they look the information and then then they read about it an it's it's really helpful for them.
So yes.
They're using it.
Thanks for the presentation.
I have a question.
OK here, OK, so you said you're using Drugbank?
What are the other sources for drug interactions?
That is for drunk and second question, how often do you update those?
Four yes, we're using drugbank for drug interactions.
Then we are using a national drug file.
Which now.
Stop the.
Stop supporting these.
This part of National drug file and we have the information extracted from the summaries of product characteristics.
So we have like these three sources.
And what was the 2nd part?
Yes, about the updating updating.
Yes, we most of the process is covered by the ETL process an we are.
It depends on the data source.
For example, matches updated at once a year.
But the local datasets are updated on a monthly basis.
So we updated on a monthly basis.
Can you give us a sense of the scale?
The size of the data?
What triplestore you used?
If you have had the scalability issues, yes we are using virtual so now the interlinked datasets are about I think 120 million triples.
But most of it is the data from the text, because we really.
Parse it into the structure.
It means like we have paragraphs an like, titles and everything.
And I think that working with these is.
Is OK and virtuoso, but when you want to really fast sparkle queries you you have to optimize it in some kind of way like building the Application Mart or something.
Otherwise it takes like several seconds and no one wants to.
No one wants to wait like 2 seconds or until the page loads.
I think that we can agree on that, so if that's enough.
Thanks a lot.
Yeah kogan.
Thank you.
